tossups.question: This writer names the “era” of art criticism that Michael Fried examined in Absorption and Theatricality. A long argument in a novel by this author interrupts the narrator’s attempt to watch a chess game between Philidor and Legall. This author wrote an erotic novel about a Congolese king who owns a ring that makes vaginas talk. This man’s most famous project began with the idea of translating a collection by Ephraim Chambers. This author of The (*) Indiscreet Jewels also wrote a novel in which the servant Jacques recounts his amorous conquests. Novels by this man include Rameau’s Nephew and Jacques the Fatalist. With Jean d’Alembert, this man headed an early modern project of knowledge gathering. For 10 points, name this head editor of the Encyclopédie.

tossups.question: Sabine Hyland wrote a history of this civilization that discusses the controversial "Naples documents" and the Jesuit Blas Valera's ("BLAHSS VUH-leh-ruhz") life with this civilization. Certain objects in this civilization may have been arranged in a 3-D grid in order to convey information. The "paradox" of this civilization is why it was the largest Bronze Age civilization to not evidently develop a (*) writing system. This civilization conveyed linguistic and numerical information through knotted ropes called quipu ("KEE-poo"), which were carried by runners on this civilization's extensive roads. Despite the offer of a room full of gold, this civilization's last emperor Atahualpa ("ah-tah-WALL-pah") was executed by Francisco Pizarro. For 10 points, name this empire that built a site at Machu Picchu and was located in the Andes.

tossups.question: The Petersen graph is the smallest in a class named for a work by this author and is not planar because the four color map theorem is true. An anecdote from one of this author's books names a theory for the constant extinction rate of species, as well as one for the existence of sexual reproduction; each hinges on an organism’s need to adapt fast enough. Melanie Bayley originated the theory that this lecturer at Christ Church had penned their best-known work as a satire of recent developments in (*) maths. That work by this author contains a famous caricature of the effects of mercury poisoning on members of the hattery business. For 10 points, name this author of nonsensical works full of wordplay, such as The Hunting of the Snark and Through The Looking Glass, and What Alice Found There.
tossups.answer: Lewis Carroll [or Charles Lutwidge Dodgson] (the first clue describes snarks; the second describes the Red Queen hypotheses)

tossups.question: This number is the lowest order of rotational symmetry limited by the crystallographic restriction theorem and hence the lowest order unique to quasicrystals. The atom being attacked is bound to this many groups in the intermediate of an SN2 (“S-N-2”) reaction. In linear molecules, there are only this number of non-vibrational degrees of freedom because two rotational axes are equivalent. (*) Pyrroles (“PIE-rolls”) are among the aromatic molecules with rings of this many atoms, thanks to two double bonds and the lone pair contributed by elements with this many valence electrons, like nitrogen. This is one more than the number of bonds typically formed by carbon. For 10 points, give this atomic number of boron.

parts: Name this anion which is moved between proteins by kinases (“KAI-nay-ses”). The addition of one or more of this anion distinguishes a nucleotide from a nucleoside.

The bond between the second and third phosphates on this molecule is a major source of energy for chemical reactions in the cell. Over thirty of this molecule are produced from glucose during cell respiration.

This glycosaminoglycan (“gly-cos-amino-gly-can”) has the most dense negative charge of any molecule found in the body due to its high number of phosphates. Fractionated examples of this molecule have a more consistent effect and can be used without monitoring of partial thromboplastin time.

parts: Name this region of the seafloor that stretches from the shoreline to the break. This region is the most landward component of the margin and has been largely exposed by past glaciations.

Much of the sediment on the shelf is sourced from terrestrial erosion; by contrast, sediment of this type dominates the abyssal plain. The presence of 30% or more sediment with this designation defines an ooze, which can be further divided into calcareous (“cal-CARE-ee-ous”) or siliceous (“sill-EE-she-ous”) varieties.

Diatomaceous oozes are particularly prevalent along this geographic feature due to the high nutrient load from upwelling. The trade winds diverge on either side of this feature, which has no Coriolis deflection and the sun directly overhead at noon.

The 39th chapter of this biblical book refers to the re’em, and contains a section in which God speaks to its title prophet in the form of a whirlwind. The section contrasts the wisdom of God with the title figure’s ignorance, causing him to repent and regain his wealth.

The 34th chapter of this Biblical book describes a “land soaked with blood” after the arrival of the re’em. The phrase “swords to ploughshares” originated in this book, which contains the “servant songs”.
